close_symbols: OS_StatusToString function prototype / declaration (including parameter attributes/annotations)
Any non-null / nullable annotation macros or attribute definitions used in prototypes (e.g. NONNULL, OS_NONNULL, __attribute__((nonnull)), _Nullable/_Nonnull)
All call sites of OS_StatusToString (source locations of callers)
explanation:
1) os_status_string_t (typedef/definition): The controlling expression is status_string != NULL and the code dereferences *status_string and uses sizeof(*status_string). The exact typedef (e.g. char[NN], char *, or other) changes pointer/indirection semantics and may reveal compile-time properties (array vs pointer) that affect whether tests can be considered invariant.  
2) OS_StatusToString function prototype / declaration (including parameter attributes/annotations): The prototype may carry attributes (e.g. static analysis annotations, restricted/nonnull qualifiers, or other compiler attributes) that formally require callers to never pass NULL; such annotations would make the conditional effectively invariant by contract and must be considered when applying the MISRA rule.  
3) Any non-null / nullable annotation macros or attribute definitions used in prototypes (e.g. NONNULL, OS_NONNULL, __attribute__((nonnull)), _Nullable/_Nonnull): These macros/attributes definitions are needed to interpret annotations found on the prototype or in project headers; they determine whether the status_string parameter is guaranteed non-NULL by API contract.  
4) All call sites of OS_StatusToString (source locations of callers): To decide if the controlling expression is invariant in the whole program, you must inspect callers to see whether they always pass a non-NULL (or always NULL) argument. If every call site unconditionally supplies a non-NULL pointer, the expression is invariant in practice; if some callers pass NULL, it is not invariant. Inspecting callers is therefore necessary for a complete MISRA assessment.
